required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Immune Responses to the Flu Shot During Pregnancy
clinical_study.official_title: Immune Responses to the Flu Shot During Pregnancy

brief_summary.textblock: This study will examine effects of everyday life stress and obesity on immune responses to influenza virus vaccine (the flu shot) during pregnancy. Following vaccination, antibody levels against influenza (the flu) increase. Higher antibody levels indicate better immune protection from influenza. In addition to providing protection from the flu for yourself, being vaccinated during pregnancy may protect your baby from the flu during the first six months of life during which time infants cannot be vaccinated. Our primary goals are to determine whether greater life stress and obesity reduce 1) antibody responses to the flu shot in women and 2) antibody levels in the newborn at the time of delivery.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: antibody responses to the flu shot in women
primary_outcome.time_frame: 1 month post vaccination and at delivery

arm_group.description: pregnant women receive a seasonal influenza virus vaccination

intervention.description: comparison of immune responses to the flu vaccine in obese and non-obese populations

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- less than 29 weeks pregnant
- ages 18-42
- planning to deliver at The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center
Exclusion Criteria:
- prior serious adverse reaction to seasonal influenza vaccine

overall_official.affiliation: The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center

facility.name: The Ohio State University Wexner Medical Center

link.description: For more information or to apply
